pathway.label: YOUR ROAD
pathway.title:
Know what you need.

Get there.
pathway.description: Ontario requires specific training before you step on site. Some are free, some aren't — we mapped the path so you don't have to figure it out alone.
pathway.trigger_desc: Required certifications, free government courses, and partner training
pathway.intro: Every construction worker in Ontario needs certain certifications to work legally and safely. Here's the roadmap — from your first day on site to specialized credentials.

step1.title: Worker Health & Safety Awareness in 4 Steps
step1.description: Required by law for all Ontario workers. Free online.

step2.title: WHMIS 2025 — Hazardous Materials
step2.description: Required near hazardous products. Free online.

step3.title: Working at Heights
step3.description: Mandatory with fall protection. Refresher every 3 years.

step4.title: Forklift / Powered Mobile Equipment
step4.description: Required to operate forklifts, boom lifts, and powered equipment.

step5.title: Supervisor Health & Safety Awareness in 5 Steps
step5.description: For supervisor roles. Free government course.

step6.title: Confined Space Entry
step6.description: Required for confined space work on construction sites.

step7.title: First Aid & CPR Certification
step7.description: At least one certified person required on site at all times.

step8.title: PPE, Fire Safety, Ground Disturbance & More
step8.description: Trade-specific. May be required by your employer.

pathway.cta_title: Save your progress — sign up as Member
pathway.cta_desc: Track your certifications, store certificates, and see your progress. All in one place, without jumping between sites.

community.manifesto_lead: Buildings don't remember who built them. We do.
community.manifesto_body: This city didn't build itself. Somebody woke up before the sun, scraped ice, put on boots that already hurt, and made something real. OnSite Club exists because that somebody deserves more than a paycheck. They deserve a name on what they built. We make gear, tools, and a crew for the people whose work everyone sees but nobody credits. If you've ever looked at a skyline and known your hands are in it — this is your club.
